If points $A$, $B$, and $C$ are distinct with $B$ on the segment $AC$ or beyond it, then the angle at $C$ formed by the lines $AC$ and $BC$ is zero.

type:
‚àÄ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ‚Ñù V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]

name: Wbtw.angle‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ_eq_zero_of_ne
docString: If points $A$, $B$, and $C$ are distinct with $B$ on the segment $AC$ or beyond it, then the angle at $C$ formed by the lines $AC$ and $BC$ is zero.

This theorem states that in Euclidean geometry, given any three points A, B, and C where B is the vertex, if the angle ‚à†ABC (angle between line segment AB and BC) is pi (œÄ, i.e., 180 degrees), then the angle ‚à†BAC (angle between line segment BA and AC) is 0. In other words, if the line segments AB and BC are in a straight line, then A, B, and C are collinear and the angle at A looking towards B and then C is zero. This theorem holds for any normed additive commutative group, inner product space, metric space, and normed additive torsor.

type:
‚àÄ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ‚Ñù V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] {p1 p2 p3 : P},
  EuclideanGeometry.angle p1 p2 p3 = Real.pi ‚Üí EuclideanGeometry.angle p2 p1 p3 = 0
name: EuclideanGeometry.angle_eq_zero_of_angle_eq_pi_left
docString: This theorem states that in Euclidean geometry, given any three points A, B, and C where B is the vertex, if the angle ‚à†ABC (angle between line segment AB and BC) is pi (œÄ, i.e., 180 degrees), then the angle ‚à†BAC (angle between line segment BA and AC) is 0. In other words, if the line segments AB and BC are in a straight line, then A, B, and C are collinear and the angle at A looking towards B and then C is zero. This theorem holds for any normed additive commutative group, inner product space, metric space, and normed additive torsor.

Given a tetrahedron in three-dimensional space with opposite edges [x, p] and [y, q], and a triangle with vertices p, q, and z on the line segment [x, y], the segment [u, v] joining the edges [x, p] and [y, q] intersects or lies in the convex hull of {p, q, z}.

type:
‚àÄ {ùïú : Type u_1} {E : Type u_2} [inst : LinearOrderedField ùïú] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup E] [inst_2 : Module ùïú E]
  {p q u v x y z : E},
  z ‚àà segment ùïú x y ‚Üí u ‚àà segment ùïú x p ‚Üí v ‚àà segment ùïú y q ‚Üí ¬¨Disjoint (segment ùïú u v) ((convexHull ùïú) {p, q, z})

docString: Given a tetrahedron in three-dimensional space with opposite edges [x, p] and [y, q], and a triangle with vertices p, q, and z on the line segment [x, y], the segment [u, v] joining the edges [x, p] and [y, q] intersects or lies in the convex hull of {p, q, z}.

This theorem states that in a Euclidean space, if the angle at point C formed by points B and D (denoted as ‚à†BCD) is equal to œÄ (180 degrees), then the angle at point B formed by points A and C (denoted as ‚à†ABC) is equal to the angle at point B formed by points A and D (denoted as ‚à†ABD). In other words, if a straight line (BCD) is formed in a Euclidean space, then the angles subtended by the line segments with the same endpoint (ABC and ABD) are equal.

type:
‚àÄ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ‚Ñù V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]

  EuclideanGeometry.angle p2 p3 p4 = Real.pi ‚Üí EuclideanGeometry.angle p1 p2 p3 = EuclideanGeometry.angle p1 p2 p4
name: EuclideanGeometry.angle_eq_angle_of_angle_eq_pi
docString: This theorem states that in a Euclidean space, if the angle at point C formed by points B and D (denoted as ‚à†BCD) is equal to œÄ (180 degrees), then the angle at point B formed by points A and C (denoted as ‚à†ABC) is equal to the angle at point B formed by points A and D (denoted as ‚à†ABD). In other words, if a straight line (BCD) is formed in a Euclidean space, then the angles subtended by the line segments with the same endpoint (ABC and ABD) are equal.

lies in the circumsphere of the triangle.

`z ‚àà [x, y]`.

type:
‚àÄ {ùïú : Type u_1} {E : Type u_2} [inst : LinearOrderedField ùïú] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup E] [inst_2 : Module ùïú E]

The circumsphere of a triangle may be expressed explicitly in terms of two points and the
angle at the third point.

type:
‚àÄ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ‚Ñù V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] [hd2 : Fact (FiniteDimensional.finrank ‚Ñù V = 2)] [inst_4 : Module.Oriented ‚Ñù V (Fin 2)]
  (t : Affine.Triangle ‚Ñù P) {i‚ÇÅ i‚ÇÇ i‚ÇÉ : Fin 3},
  i‚ÇÅ ‚â† i‚ÇÇ ‚Üí
    i‚ÇÅ ‚â† i‚ÇÉ ‚Üí
      i‚ÇÇ ‚â† i‚ÇÉ ‚Üí
        Affine.Simplex.circumsphere t =
          {
            center :=
              ((Real.Angle.tan
                        (EuclideanGeometry.oangle (Affine.Simplex.points t i‚ÇÅ) (Affine.Simplex.points t i‚ÇÇ)
                          (Affine.Simplex.points t i‚ÇÉ)))‚Åª¬π /
                    2) ‚Ä¢
                  (Orientation.rotation EuclideanGeometry.o ‚Üë(Real.pi / 2))
                    (Affine.Simplex.points t i‚ÇÉ -·µ• Affine.Simplex.points t i‚ÇÅ) +·µ•
                midpoint ‚Ñù (Affine.Simplex.points t i‚ÇÅ) (Affine.Simplex.points t i‚ÇÉ),
            radius :=
              dist (Affine.Simplex.points t i‚ÇÅ) (Affine.Simplex.points t i‚ÇÉ) /
                  |Real.Angle.sin
                      (EuclideanGeometry.oangle (Affine.Simplex.points t i‚ÇÅ) (Affine.Simplex.points t i‚ÇÇ)
                        (Affine.Simplex.points t i‚ÇÉ))| /
                2 }
name: Affine.Triangle.circumsphere_eq_of_dist_of_oangle
docString:
The circumsphere of a triangle may be expressed explicitly in terms of two points and the
angle at the third point.

type:
{C : Type u_1} ‚Üí
  [inst : CategoryTheory.Category.{u_2, u_1} C] ‚Üí
    [inst_1 : CategoryTheory.Preadditive C] ‚Üí
      [inst_2 : CategoryTheory.Limits.HasZeroObject C] ‚Üí
        [inst_3 : CategoryTheory.HasShift C ‚Ñ§] ‚Üí
          [inst_4 : ‚àÄ (n : ‚Ñ§), CategoryTheory.Functor.Additive (CategoryTheory.shiftFunctor C n)] ‚Üí
            [inst_5 : CategoryTheory.Pretriangulated C] ‚Üí
              {X‚ÇÅ X‚ÇÇ X‚ÇÉ Z‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ Z‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ Z‚ÇÅ‚ÇÉ : C} ‚Üí
                {u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ : X‚ÇÅ ‚ü∂ X‚ÇÇ} ‚Üí
                  {u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ : X‚ÇÇ ‚ü∂ X‚ÇÉ} ‚Üí
                    {u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÉ : X‚ÇÅ ‚ü∂ X‚ÇÉ} ‚Üí
                      (comm : CategoryTheory.CategoryStruct.comp u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ = u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÉ) ‚Üí
                        {v‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ : X‚ÇÇ ‚ü∂ Z‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ} ‚Üí
                          {w‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ : Z‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ ‚ü∂ (CategoryTheory.shiftFunctor C 1).obj X‚ÇÅ} ‚Üí
                            {h‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ :
                                CategoryTheory.Pretriangulated.Triangle.mk u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ v‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ w‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ ‚àà
                                  CategoryTheory.Pretriangulated.distinguishedTriangles} ‚Üí
                              {v‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ : X‚ÇÉ ‚ü∂ Z‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ} ‚Üí
                                {w‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ : Z‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ ‚ü∂ (CategoryTheory.shiftFunctor C 1).obj X‚ÇÇ} ‚Üí
                                  {h‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ :
                                      CategoryTheory.Pretriangulated.Triangle.mk u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ v‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ w‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ ‚àà
                                        CategoryTheory.Pretriangulated.distinguishedTriangles} ‚Üí
                                    {v‚ÇÅ‚ÇÉ : X‚ÇÉ ‚ü∂ Z‚ÇÅ‚ÇÉ} ‚Üí
                                      {w‚ÇÅ‚ÇÉ : Z‚ÇÅ‚ÇÉ ‚ü∂ (CategoryTheory.shiftFunctor C 1).obj X‚ÇÅ} ‚Üí
                                        {h‚ÇÅ‚ÇÉ :
                                            CategoryTheory.Pretriangulated.Triangle.mk u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÉ v‚ÇÅ‚ÇÉ w‚ÇÅ‚ÇÉ ‚àà
                                              CategoryTheory.Pretriangulated.distinguishedTriangles} ‚Üí
                                          CategoryTheory.Triangulated.Octahedron comm h‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ h‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ h‚ÇÅ‚ÇÉ ‚Üí
                                            CategoryTheory.Pretriangulated.Triangle C
